UPDATED: JAN 2, 2017 Thanks to MaltOMeal for bringing this to the May tasting and helping me complete all styles. Pours a cloudy orange with a small frothy off white head that quickly diminishes. The aroma is a floral and lemon. Thin mouthfeel with apple and light hop with a lingering dry finish. really enjoyed this.

De cam oud lambiek. 750ml purchased from west lakeview... Pours a semi- transparent orangey brown, copper penny-like and topped with a barely present wispy white film... Aroma is grassy and solid lamic/geueze like note with a funky but subdued presence...Flavors have a soft quality to it, lighty acidic with a cheesy farmhouse aspect which contributes some character. Soft to somewhat thin bodied but delectable in a sense. A softer grassy bitterness surfaces in the backend. Classic geueze qualities throughout. Very nice all around with no obvious faults except for its own pricetag.
9/4/8/3/16

botteldatum 10/2000. Aroma of moist wood, cellar, manure, gunpowder, citrus and rose. Taste of old cellar, mould, lemon, apricot, pineapple and sour candy. Finishes slightly bitter. Not very acidic but with a kind of soft sourness. Smooth mouthfeel with low carbonation. Delicious!

2000 Vintage 750ml bottle @ Pikkulintu, Helsinki

Pours orange with a small head. Aroma has notes of fruits and berries. Taste is quite sour with notes of hops, berries, grapefruit and other fruits. Smooth, slightly sticky finish. Good, well balanced.

750 ml bottle @ Olutravintola Pikkulintu, Helsinki. Bottled @ 10/2000.
Pours a hazy dark orange colour with a small foamy head. Aroma of very strong and sour apricot and floral notes. Flavour of lovely sour apricot, strong grapefruit and some floral notes again. Lovely sour, grapefruit-like finish with a dry, sour finish. Lovely.

BottleBottle shared by phaleslu-  thanks a ton peter, really excited to try this.  Tried along side de cam kriek and oude  gueuze. This was favorite of the bunch.   Notes of tangy bright white grapes and dry leathery basement funk.  Heavy lactic acid sourness.  Dry oak.  Some grapefruit and grape fruit character.  Bitter.  Much more drinkable than typical unblinded lambic. Great beer.

750 ml bottle via local trade. Thanks, Sean! Pours a mostly clear pale gold color with a good amount of rising carbonation and a big white head. Notes of tart lemon citrus, strong oaky funk, straw, white grape skins, and lactic acid. Medium-bodied, with sharp carbonation and a tart, funky mouthfeel. Hard to describe, except really awesome.
Bottle at Ungstrups - Thanks. Pouras a hazy golden with a white head. Sweet and sour. Freshness. Hints of vanilla and pepper. Medium to light bodied. Very soft carbonation. Dry finish.

Big bottle, vintage 2001, shared with friends @Oud Arsenaal, Antwerpen. Virtually no head. Straw colored with an orangey shade. Good clarity. Clean smelling, dry and tart fruity. Fine notes of cheese, leather and horse stable. Taste has a dry and light acidic-sour grapefruity and lemony fruitiness. A subtle and mellowing sweetness underneath. Light horsey with cellar notes. Not very full. Tart sappy fruitiness in the ending. Overall a highly drinkable and well matured Lambik.

Bottle from MaltOMeal.  Thanks!Pours a deep cheddar orange with a nose of cedar, lemon, barnyard, and old men talking.  Flavor is dry cedar, leather, and horseblanket.  Every sip is a mouthpuckering orgasm.  WOW.
user_location: Ugly, Hot, and Humid Spring, Texas, USA

text: Bottle shared by maltomeal (who was on a roll) at the May 2011 Houston tasting. Bright gold and clear. Nose of smelly feet and old socks. Taste is supremely tart and earthy, with tons of funkiness. Oh my teeth hurt on this one! Puckery and so delicious. Great beer-I love this style.
user_location: Seattle still not near Beersel., Washington, USA

text: Verhaltener Antrunk ohne spürbare Säuerlichkeit. Diese setzt erst später ein, dazu ist es sehr trocken und minimal hopfig. Weiterhin etwas wässrig, zum Ende aromatischer und wenig sauer. Allgemein ein rundes und stimmiges, aber erst spät wirklich gut werdendes Lambiek. 11/9/10/12//11

Bottle that I shared at the May Houston RB Tasting.  This should be my last style needed.  Pours a cloudy amber with a thin, white head.  Nose is of shoe polish, funky cheese and sour fruit.  Wow!  Taste is of funky cheese.  Mouthfeel is thin, sour and dry.  Very good stuff.

Thanks to Maltomeal for bringing this beer. Pours a golden color with small white head. Nose of horseblanket, lemon, some soft spices. Flavor is wonderful sourness with some cheese, hay, and oak...very nice.

Vintage bottle shared by OSCF - thanks, Todd! My notes say: "Titties!" Theres more but maybe there neednt be. Crisp pale golden pour, with a surprisingly vigorous head and carbonation for a beer getting on over a decade. Nicely funky nose, tart and citric, deeply aged funk. Body is lively and prickly still. Raw rind in the flavor and tons of it, amazing how fresh tasting the beer is if youre into this kind of thing. Lovely acetic bloom towards the finish. Yummy.

750ml bottle.  It pours an unclear, orange, with some white bubbles on top. Barnyard aromas blend with citric and sour scents and is quite pleasant. Citric and acidic flavor with barnyard as well. Astringent, medium mouth feel. It is a nice lambic, but a bit anonymous.

2000 Bottle shared by Todd.  Thanks, man!  Pours a bright gold with one-finger white head. Nose shows lots of leather, old lemon and wood, funk and acid.  Rotten lemon peel, but in a good way.  The age is clearly there, but the acidity is still hanging on nicely. Tart.  Nice palate.

UPDATED: JUN 9, 2012 2003 bottle that came to the states in 2011.
A: Orangish-straw yellow body.  Slight bubbly head that crashes quickly after the pour.
S: Nice mild funky aroma.  Wet hay, musty oak, biting citric hues, mild sweat, and a little cheese-like funk.
T: Amped up version of the nose.  Funky like any good lambiek should be,  Lots of sweaty/musty barnyard notes with some softer accents of citrus and oak.
M: Medium bodied.  Only the slightest hints of carbonation.
O: Nice to have a oude lambiek available in bottle form.

Big thanks to Eric for hosting us and breaking out this and quite a few other great Belgian brews. 2000 vintage served in a mini snifter.

Pours a light golden color without a much of any head formation even after a fairly-hard pour. A few bubbles on top throughout. The nose is really quite funky with a good deal of barnyard character along with some leather and earth. Just very funky.

The flavor adds in some good notes of citrus and rind underneath the hay, funk, and wet leather that the nose had pulled together. The finish is quite excellent with a slight sourness and a beautiful dryness. Carbonation is light throughout and this goes down quite well. Thanks again, Eric.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 12-07-2010

2000 vintage provided by Eric, thank you...Pours dark peach with some light carbonation, not much of note...A strong aroma, acidic horse blanket, slightly sulfuric, rotten eggs, blue cheese. I typically love the sour ones, something just off about this. Too much off barnyard and spoiled food aromas...The taste is much better than the aroma, more evenly balanced. Some vinegar balances the horse blanket, but adds some lemon notes. A sour metallic finish puts me off again.

I had high hopes for this and although its above average, doesnt meet my wild expectations for De Cam or a 10 year old lambic.
Bottle...  Poured golden/orange with a thin, bubbly white head.  Great tartness and some funk with citrus, lemon and mild barnyard, musky burn.

golden orange pour, slight offwhite head.  Perfect pour by Carl.  Aroma is savory herbals, hay, Old Lambic, relatively clean, only a touch of funk.  Mouthfeel is light, slippery.  Flavor is musty gueze, citrus, nectar, cellar, subtle, delicious.  Really damn good.

Hazy peach pour with minimal head. The nose is full of barnyard, basement must, cheesecloth, lemon astringency, wet hay, and a touch of herbal presence as well. Absolutely lovely lambic aroma. Flavor is fantastic; more wet hay, horseblanket, tons of lemon and must, and a fairly clean finish. Not abrasively acidic at the finish, rather clean in fact. Palate is delightfully sour and tasty. Great brew.

Thanks craftycarl21 with a proper lambic pour! The pour is hazy amber with no head. The nose is vibrant must, cheese cloth, barnyard, horse coat, lemon peel, and hay. The flavor holds hugely vibrant musty hay with lemon acidity, farmy funk, and basement. The palate is medium bodied with an epically acidic texture and a dry finish.

Pours a bright clean gold with one finger of white head. Nose is super funky and acidic with lots of barnyard notes and citrus zest. Flavor is bracingly acidic with notes of lemon rind and horse blanket. Tart palate and light body.
Botella. Nice golden orange colour. Pleasant fruity tart aroma. Flavour is really yummy, fruity and tart, dry, some sweetness too underneath that so good sourness, bit wood. So so so good!

750 cc from a PUBN groupie.  Pours dark straw, clear, with minimal white head.  Nose is sour mashy tart fruit, lactic acidity, woody, funky and female tainty.  Tastes tart, fruity, lactic, acidic with earthy notes, funk, and a tart crisp finish.  A great lambic
Vintage 2000 bottle shared by OSCF.  Thanks Todd.  Poured deep orange and still.  Leather, citrus, funk, cobwebs, horseblanket.  Woody with a good helping of baryard funk.  Lovely.

750ml corked and caged green bottle.

It pours a hazy amber color with a frothy white that leaves surprising lacing.

The smell is pretty enthralling. There is a huge funk that is the main theme with some barnyard and must. There is a definite spice element that is almost woody as well, though the barrels are over 100 years old and are probably filled to the pore with bugs and bacteria. There is some pear and chamomile as well.

It is sour and acidic, with a lot of lemon and vinegar. There is a hint of green tomato. The funk is more subdued in the taste but is still there. The aftertaste is sightly bitter and sour.

The mouthfeel is perfect. It is slightly carbed but still rather flat. It is tart and puckering.

A fantastic brew.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 03-06-2011 05:59:41

750ml Bottle:  Armoma of Lambiek, oak, barnyard, leather, slight vinegar, slight fruit, and sourness.  Poured amber/orange in color with a tiny, off-white head that disappeared immediately.  Cloudy.  Lightly sparkling.  Flavor is medium tart and medium sweet.  Tastes of Lambic, light fruit, oak, wood, and barnyard.  Light to medium body.  Thin, lightly dry texture.  Average carbonation.  Lambic, oak, wood, tart fruit finish is lightly dry.

Bottled sample (2000 vintage), shared with Savvy1982 and oakbluff. Orange in colour and virtually still. Intense floral aroma (especially for a lambic this old), along with notes of feet, lemon, herbs, and wet wood. Flavours are mellow with more driftwood and lemon, along with a restrained herbal funkiness. Gently sour, and not overly tart on the palate. What it lacks in abrasiveness is more than made up for with the balance, complexity, and intensity of the aroma and flavours. A great undblended experience.

A 2003 bottle I brought to Damico sour tasting on 05-Mar-2011. Pour a slightly hazy dark golden yellow with little head. Nice carbonation though mouth feel is great, a sour but some how a nice balanced sweetness, honeydu mellon, but still funky and sharp tarness to sour. Really nice stuff.

thanks Tom, excited to get to try this! .. . pours a deep orange tan, pretty much no foam .. . nice funky pucker, wood and sour fruit skins . .. a nice lambirdbeak, wonder where a decade would put this.. . Crazy? Crazy like a fox!

Bottle at the 5th Annual Richmond Industry Gathering on 11/28/2010. Hazy orange body with a small white head. Tart fruit aroma. Sweet fruit flavor with a bit of tartness. Medium light body with moderately high carbonation.

Bottle courtesy piscator34. Thanks Kris! Pours clear, flat orange. No head, spotty lacing. Nose is floral? Why is this so floral? So florals, plus sour apples, leather, notes of ink? Lovely nose, regardless. Flavours of leather and horseblanket, mostly dry but with a hint of sweetness in the finish. Almost seems rich, which seems odd to say about lambic. A beer of contrasts, that is greater than the sum of its parts.

2000 bottle shared by deflagro and pundarquartis, thanks guys.
clear orange,small white head.
fruity aroma, citrus, dry.
flavor is dry, leather, fruit peel, well blended, fresh and fruity.

Hazy orange, with a surprising but still scant white cover.  Aroma is very dry, musty horseblanket, acidic tartness.  Taste is funky, tart, dry, light paper, horseblanket, basement, acidic finish. 5 year old bottle thanks to grownfool.
2003 vintage shared at Mikeys tasting. Pours clear orange. Nose is tart and strong funky fruit and orange rind. Taste is dry tart fruit, orange rind, lemon zest and funk. Dryish finish.

This is only my second unblended lambic. How bout that? huh? Anyway, I always have trouble rating lambics in general because the taste like what they are. I mean, there only so many ways to say sour, right? I can say that this one had steel notes, smokey notes, lemony notes, but you probably knew that already. So It sum up, it was good. 2005 Vintage.

750, corked and baled. Pours a cloudy bright toffeeish medium orange. Densely bubbled head across the top, it just lasts and lasts and lasts. Sharply, aggressively tart nose, very piercing, lots of oranges and heavily acidic pucker. Poopy funk and some minerally dryness, too, and this is all on the nose. Creamy medium body with very lively carb. Oranges, funk, basement, barnyard, and fruit rind on the mid-palate. Mild, refreshing finish with a bracing puckery bite. Great lambic. Would greedily drink it all the time...if it werent $2 an ounce.

03 bottle @ Deep Ellum. Birthday beer. Hazy orange, flat. Aroma - wet leaves, lactic acid, honeysuckle, and... what smells unmistakably like semen, no joke. Flavor - lots of wood, quite sour, lactic acid. Flat of course, and very mellow. Very good. Is it $40 good? No, but still very good.

12.31.10 - This I believe is a 2003 vintage.  on the label it says " exclusief" - from a batch of 1800 bottles imported to the states this year. 750ml cage and cork.   Pours a light hazy orange with no head.  Smells a slight citrus maybe some apple.  Overall an excellent bottle, finished it no problem.  Definitely sour with a lemony finish.  As good or better than any Cantillon Ive had.  Recommended, but expensive at $38.

Tasted from a corked and caged 750mL bottle purchased at Lush West Town, 2003 Vintage.  Pours hazy orange with a very thin and bubbly white head that recedes to a bubbly collar.  This beer smells magic.  I could smell it all day.  It is super tart with lemon (juice, peel, and pith), green apple, a good amount of dusty and barnyard Brett funk, gooseberry, apple cider vinegar, and just a hint of hay malt, and as it warms, a very nice oaky vanilla component.  The flavor is very acidic starting with lemon and green apple, hay, barnyard funk, gooseberry, a good amount of fruit (green apple and lemon) peel which provides a large amount of drying tannin on the center of my tongue.  The body is light with almost no carbonation whatsoever, and a long lemon and green apple peel finish.  There is also a good amount of both acid and tannin present in this beer.

Bottle shared by Shane, thanks! Poured a cloudy golden amber with no head whatsoever. Aroma was quite funky with a menthol note coming through. There was also a strong sour note with just a bit of wet hay. Flavor began sour and was joined by a menthol with a funky and earthy underlying grain/hay note.

Thanks to Santa for this!  HAzy Amber pour with a thin white head.   No lace to speak of.  Aroma of lactic acid, horsey, white grape and oak.    Complex flavor with subtle hints of horse blanket, dusty grape skin, oak.   Dry finish. Low to moderate acidity.  Very nice glad to have tried this

3 years old on the bottle, no bottled date found, told later it is 2003.  Gentle soft persistent tartness, little cracker meal, some bubbly carbonation also with belly button.  Hazy yellowed amber, sparse white head.  Straight lacto, kind of soft in body, some honey and lemon juice in the finish, gentle.

3 year old lambiek.  Pours a hazy ruddy gold with the faintest layer of white head.  The aroma is mouthwatering even from a distance.  Hay, dust, mold, and yeast round out the intensely sour aroma.  The body is very tart with a mouth puckering lemon finish.  Very dusty with plenty of barnyard.

One of the highlights of the 5th Epic and Rare gathering.  2001 bottling.  Medium, hazy gold.  Aroma and flavor were a match - pleasant soft horseblanket, hay, and barnyard.  I know that isnt much, but this was a simple, straightforward, beautiful lambic.  Just dont get stuff like this often enough.  Freakin awesome.

2001 vintage at the 5th Annual Epic Beer Tasting in Richmond, VA, November 28, 2010. Pours a hazy orange with nearly no head. Aroma of tart, vinous notes. Earthy, citrus and stone fruits also. The taste is citrus, earthy, strong musty funk, and a vinous, almost olive-like note. Very dry. Soft carbonation, medium bodied. Nice beer.

O-town Throwdown III at Boboskis.  2005 vintage.  Pours a hazy dirty bronze with a thin white head and light delicate carbonation.  Aroma is apple juice, woody, oak, wood stain mahogany resin and slight varnish, phenolic, esters, goaty funky cheese, brett barnyard and even gets close to the smell of Red Bull as it warms.  Flavor is woody, grapeskins, vinous, phenolic, apple skin and apple tartness, lactic acid bacteria, funky brett, horsey, leather, grass, and old cheese funk.  Moderate acidity, allows it to be very soft and rounded, lots of woody oak, slightly old though, musty, with some earthy tones in the end- dry and woody but not astringent or harsh like an over-woody boon, etc.  Very nice overall.
(bottle dated 03.2000) hazy gold, no head; aromas - musty, bit of basement, medicinal; flavour - sour, clean, bit of funk, touch of mineral finish

Had this at BCTC after the fest, back at the campsite, bottle from 2000, courtesy of Rudy.  Pours a hazy orange with a thin white head. Cheesy, faint funk and sourness.  Vinegar, cheesiness, sweet tarts.  Long tingly sour.  Quite smooth.

2 years old lambic, served cask conditioned at Moeder Lambic Fontainas. Cloudy golden pour with a small, bubbly white head. Solid aroma of sourness, acidity, fruits and cheese. The flavor is acidic, lactic/cheesy and fruity, it also has a white wine quality. The body is light with a dusty, cobwebby mouthfeel and very low carbonation. Splendid.

Big thanks to Jeremy for this one!  2000 Vintage.

A-pours a golden orange wood color witha thinner pure white head.

S-the nose has a lot of malt in it, notes of wheat with a good earthy funk to it and notes of meadow.  just a hint of acidity with lemon notes in the back.

T-extremely smooth and subtle, the flavors are full but nothing dominates another.  funk is there, meadowy earthy funk, fresh and free, notes of unripe peach and lemon with a light acidity in the back.

M-extremely soft and easy to drink, light body, great carbonation, not dry but a crisp clean finish.

D-this has a huge drinkability factor to it, everything is very soft and subtle with a nice balance to it.

UPDATED: JAN 21, 2011 Hazy golden color with a small, white head that left nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma of brett, wood, earth, wild yeast, citrus, and barnyard.  Taste of soured wild yeast, light apple wood, and a bone dry finish.  Thanks to Rudy for sharing!
BCTC 2010, courtesy of Rudolf I believe. golden flat pour. sharp acidic tartness, funk earthiness. sharp acidity in the flavor, not tongue scraping but still pretty tart. very nice

2000 Bottle vintage, sampled at Chez Moeder Lambic Fontainas; July 2010
This pours with a lightly hazed, amber tinged, still looking body.  The cork popped out though and it has formed a head upon pouring with a pale, off-white, big bubbled head.  This smells nicely of aged foot, ample wood / oak (at least for a Lambic), a spicy almost cinnamon like note, some hints of acetic acid, a light cider character and a fresh cut wood plank aroma that comes off as quite vibrant at times.  A lactic tartness anchors the nose and there are also aromas of tobacco as well as a faded cedar-woodiness.  The aroma is really quite complex and interesting and I am definitely enjoying smelling this beer.

A hint of textural fizz is here, but the beer is largely flat feeling on the tongue.  The beer is lightly sour up front, but finishes with an oak-derived astringency that accentuates the dryness of this beer and, in a complimentary fashion, the tartness.  Lots of wood character is found in the flavor with notes of fresh cut wood, a light spiciness and even some woody pepper notes.  The astringency int eh finish is joined by notes of chalk, pepper and a lactic acidity that fades with time.  This is pretty light bodied and there is just enough texture to keep this from being down right watery (it is not quite there).  The woodiness brings out flavors of mushrooms, musty cellar notes as well as some phenolic influence producing a smell like the burn of a saw blade on wood.

This is not as complex as it could be and the texture is a little flat at times, but this is a straight Lambic, so you have to expect that.  I really like the ample wood character here though.  The aroma is definitely a touch more interesting than the flavor and a bit more balanced too; the texture seems to compete with the balance in the flavor.  Overall though this is a very nice and tasty Lambic, and I would love to have a bunch of these in the cellar.

Taste thanks to Jeremy!Tan orange with a fizzy thin white ring for a head. Nose is of wheat and light mineral, also some lemon, Lightly overcarbonated and watery profile, more lemon with some faint breadcrust and spice. Mineral finish. Very mellow, pleasant, and with no offensive notes, but also a bit uninteresting.

2000 bottle.  Medium orange clear pour, thin white ring of a head that fades into nothing.  Funky, minerally on the nose.  Some vibrant lemons.  Quite a refined and balanced nose.  Pleasant flavor, refined yet lively, focusing on lemon citrus acids, a good dose of barnyard funk, and minerals.  Soft, soft flavor.  Very nice, reminds me of Crianza Helena in its refined, balanced nuances full of really expressive flavors.

A: The pour is a mildly cloudy golden straw color with very little white head.

S: This particular lambic is quite heavy on the oak--its quite musty and funky. A nice lemon and citrus rind aroma as well.

T: Like the nose, this is a very oaky/woody beer. The wood flavor is not harsh or overbearing, but certainly dominant. The lambic is still fairly tart with most of that sourness coming in the form of lemons with perhaps a hint of green apples.

M: The body is medium with a light carbonation and a dry, puckering finish.

D: While you do have to enjoy the oak component, this is still a nice lambic that is quite easy to drink.
Bottled Feb. 2001.  Crazy aroma - dust, dried herbs, old battleship oil.  Flavor is a bit flat: med.-low acidity; getting a wee bit oxidized.

Bottle from Beer Planet, Brussells. 2000 vintage. Light orange pour (unsurprisingly) with no head. Orange peel, quite zesty, cheese and lemony nose. Tangy flavours of lime, lemon zest, some fresh herbs, melted cheese, crispy fruity sour tang. Sour, zesty finish. Superb!

UPDATED: SEP 18, 2010 First bottle from the brewery, courtesy of Jean at Moeder Lambic Fontainas.  Brewed 1998, bottled 2000.  Variegated golden brown, small white head (!) with great retention (!!).  Aroma of dusty lemons.  Taste is dust, dirt, barn, grapefruit.  Nice.

Handpump at De Cam, part of the "Pruufpalet". 1,5 year old. Cloudy golden taste with a very small white head. Aroma of slight fruit, vanilla, dust. Taste is very dry and sour with a nice bite in the finish. Good lambic.

Its not often I get to try a Lambic - Unblended, and alfrantzell on BA is to thank for this one.  Bottle is vintage 2000, apparently brewed in 1995!  Oude is right!  This is oude as the hills.

Slightly hazy golden pour with no head, just some swirls on the beer.  To style on the appearance.

Aroma is nice and funky with musty old basement, cobwebs (yes Ive smelled them), leather, and a little sweet malt.  Smells great.

The flavor outdoes the aroma even.  Slightly sweet malt and loads of barnyard/basement funk.  Notes of leather and funky cheese.

Mildly tart on the palate with medium acidity and low carbonation.  Really excellent mouthfeel.

Pretty drinkable stuff.  Color me impressed.  This is a hell of a Lambic - Unblended if Ive ever seen one.

In short: The personality of an unblended lambik with the intensity of a blended Gueuze.  Wow!
How: Draft at the De Cam Volkscafe
The look: Clear blonde body topped by a small off-white ring of foam
In long: Nose of dusty carpet, dusty attic you know, old rustic stuff.  Taste of apple skin, dusty drawer, young sour apples, crisp grainy cereals, apple seeds.  Carbonation is smooth but still lively.  Very very sharp.  This beer is different from their assembled Gueuze but it is also surprisingly almost as intense.  All unblended lambics I had on tap were way softer than their respective assembled Gueuze version.  Not the case here.  This beer is just Wow!  Plus the De Cam Volkscafe is just such a nice relaxed place in a quiet little village.  Great countryside experience.  I took a break from the busy cities and pubs, relaxed, and stopped to smell the roses.  But unfortunately with the amount of lambic I was drinking during those days it didnt smell like roses.

Hazy copper colour with zero head. Funky vinegar aroma with notes of apples and hai. Smooth bodied, smooth flavoured with notes of vinegar, light barnyard and green apples. Somewhat woody and almost vinous.

Bottle, Date 10.2000. A quite sour aroma, light fruity, citrus and some menthol. The lambiek has no head, the body is golden orange and clear. The taste is very sour, later it gets a little bit sweeter, some taste of menthol as in the smell. The body is very dry, light to medium with a soft carbonation. A great lambiek!

Bottle.  Musty basement, white wine and vinegar aroma.  Clear golden amber color - lots of bubbles clinging to the side of the glass.  Sour/dry white wine and vinegar flavor.  Nice mouthfeel.  A pleasure and a great beer for #3000.

Bottle, 2000 vintage. Copper-golden, rather clear liquid with almost no head. Aroma is strong, with notes of fermented apples, wood and stables with a distinct acidity. Taste is acidic and musty but still round, a bit buttery and with notes of apples and yeast. Dry finish with some bitterness. Fantastic.

Courtesy bierkoning. Lightly hazy gold/copper, minimal white head. Plenty of barn funk, pine, citrus rind, menthol, acidity, and old wood. Medium body, smooth, dry, way too easy to drink. Great oude lambic, I could drink this stuff all day. From notes.

Draft at the De Cam Volkscafe. Sweetish, musty, somewhat fruity nose with hints of raspberry. Softly sparkling, lightly bitter, lightly sweet with a subtle tartness. Again, faint raspberry in the backdrop and aftertaste. Refreshing and enjoyable.

UPDATED: DEC 8, 2015 Re-rate 12/15: Bottle sample at a tasting at Dancing Camel. Thanks Vova. Golden. Funky aroma, very oaky and lemony. Dry flavor, oaky, lemony, with mild bitterness in the finish. Light to medium-bodied, flat. 7/3/8/3/16=3.7

Re-rate 11/13: Bottle sample at a sour tasting at  the Beer & Beyond shop. Thanks Tom L. 2009 bottle. Hazy yellow-golden. Wonderful aroma of barnyard, oak, lemony notes and cobwebs. Re-rate 5/9/12: Bottle shared by Jacob at Ølbaren in Copenhagen. Thanks! Bottled 1/09. Clear orange with a beige head. Aroma of barnyard, oak, a bit of sweat and citrus. Sour oaky flavor. Good stuff. 8/3/7/4/15=3.7

[9/6/09] Tap at De Cam Volkscafe in Gooik. Aroma of oak, cobwebs, cellar, and some fruits. A musty feel overall. Great sour flavor with wood, a bit of funk going on and some citric notes. Rounded mouthfeel. Really delicious. 8/4/8/4/17=4.1

UPDATED: JAN 3, 2010 Bottle 1995 at Akkurat and Plan B, shared with Andreassen11 and plovmand. 
Damn this is great stuff! 
Lovely dry and smooth aroma with notes of grape, humid cellar and hints of wood and dust. 
The flavour is dry and nicely balanced, with mainly ripe grape and woody notes only slightly bitter and with a late sweetness.
Splendid!
Bottle at Akkurat. Hazy yellow body with a medium white head. Aroma is wood, citrus and acid. Flavour is fruity and sour with citrus notes. Very balanced.

Bottle. Pours cloudy orange/golden coloured with a small egg white head. Dry aromas of citrus fruit, leather, wet wood, spice and barnyard. Dry and tart flavour with notes of orange fruit, rubber and wood.

A 0.75L bottle shared at Pikkulintu. Fruity nose. Clear orange colour.Sour taste. Not too hoppy. Slight notes of oak in the nose. Pale head. Some hints of lemon in the taste. Some honey notes in the nose.

Bottle marked as 10.2000 thanks to bu11zeye. Pours with no head and a hazy golden orange body. Aroma of cobwebs, light must, cork, tobacco and lemon. Taste is attic, sour and lemon. Light carbonation and a water like mouthfeel.

UPDATED: AUG 20, 2009 (Draught, 2yr old, sampled Apr 2009)  Pours a clear golden orange body with no head.  Aroma of earth, light dustiness, mold, cheese, cobwebs, horse blanket, and citrus.  Flavor of tart grapefruit, earth, and light wood. 7/3/7/3/14


(750ml, bottled 10/2000, courtesy of Geuzestekerij De Cam, sampled July 2009)  Pours a hazy golden orange body with a small bubbly white head.  Aroma of grapefruit, basement, cobwebs, and mold.  Flavor of grapefruit peel and earth with a dry finish. 8/4/7/4/15

2005 bottle shared by ygtbsm94 on 1/10/09: Clear deep golden with a thin ring of white head.  Aroma of lightly sweet citrus and doughy malts and good tart tanginess and leathery character. Bottle, bought @ Willems, Grobbendonk.
[bottled 2000]

UPDATED: AUG 20, 2009 Draft at WSF 2009. Slightly hazy golden with a small white head.  Aroma of citrus and pineapple, with funky notes. Fruity dry and tart flavour. Slightly bitter and wooden finish.

Bottled: Aroma has barnyard, grass and wood with a sweet floral touch. Dry and medium sour flavour with lots of tannin and grapefruit. Same 4.0 rating

2000 bottle @ Delirium.  Pours clear orange with white fluffy head.  Aroma full of lemon, funk, and pepper.  Taste is chock full of lemons and sourness.  Has a quick sour bite and little lingering in the finish, though this increases as the beer warms.  Very clean and crisp after all this time.  A great refresher.

(Bottle, 0.75 l - bottled 10/2005 - at Pikkulintu, Helsinki, on 2009-04-26 -- shared with JK54B, thanks!) Pale amber and hazy. Very small white head. Sourness, fruitness and wood in aroma. 37.5 cL bottle - bottled 2000, after 5 years - tasted 2009 - 14 years old, courtesy of Ungstrup - cheers Jens! Pours hazy orange with a fully gone head. Dry barnyard and orange fruity aroma. 2005. Hazed amber/deep orange pour. With few bubbles at the perimeter, no head and glistening earthtones, this is unmistakable as an unblended lambic. Levels of barnyard funk similar to offerings from 3 Fonteinen pop out of the glass. Brew-pipe styled Brettanomyces appears and settles in for the duration. Suddenly, a clean, fruity addition rears its pretty head with notes of lemon and peach. The aroma winds into further complexity with toast, horseblanket and moderate leather. Wood and musty grape leaf hints bear down as the first sip draws near. The flavor reminds initially of the greatness that is Cantillon Grand Cru, the benchmark for unblended lambics that are regularly accessible. Another comparison to a great - this is headed in the right direction - but it does have a new path to take. Solid funkiness doesnt come in waves, its quite streamlined and steady, a blanket of oak, lemony sharp acidity and earth. Orange-laden citric notes flow freely, accompanied by low-mild sweetness, medium to medium-high acidity, mild to moderate tartness that begs the next quenching sip, and medium-high sourness that never gets in the way of favorable drinkability - but it never actually eases up either. Finishes very balanced, lightly sugary, moderately tart, hay notes and old wet oak lingering. This has a sweaty suana feeling throughout. Very low carbonation, medium bodied, smooth and awkwardly salty at intermittent points throughout, especially in the brash finish. Excellent.

Bottle (2005)... This beer rocks!... Cloudy golden ale with no head. The nose is total funkarama! Well-rounded acidity tamed by moderate bitterness and ultra-restrained, toffee sweetness. Almost full-bodied with a silky mouthfeel and soft carbonation. Finishes tangy and moderately bitter. Cheers to dsnowden for sharing!
Bottle shared by sliffy. Hazy orange pour with no head. Aroma of funk and barnyard...light sour. Flavor was sour with vinous notes, more funk and yeast. Medium body, sour/funky with a sour finish.

Courtesy dsnowden.  Pours a cloudy orange, with pretty much no head.  Smells of huge acidic sourness, lemons, and tannins.  Just straight sourlicious.  The taste is lightly carbonated, with the funky sour fruits just penetrating my palate and coating it fully.  Kind of had a grapefruit bitter aftertaste and sour funked out lemons are left on the lips.  If you like crazy sour stuff, this is the beer for you.

Poured a very hazy orange, almost entirely devoid of carbonation.  Aroma is funky, funky, funky.  Grass, freshly mowed hay, a floral note, acidity, some vinegar, there is so much going on.  Flavor is acidic, there is a slightly tannic component, cutting the acidity and balancing everything out.  Awesome.
bottled. hazy golden with a steady white head. aroma of old newspapers, stale salad dressing, capers. reasonably tart, cider vinegar, young apples, tasty

Bottle, 75 cl. Bought @ Bab festival.
Cloudy orange color, very thin head. Aroma = fantastic tart gueuze, wood and some fruit. Medum body. Taste sour and tart with some wood. Very good lambic !
Hazy amber of color with a beige head. An aroma with sour notes, sour bread - no sweet notes. A pretty dry flavor - no sweets, hints of oak and wet dog.
Pours a cloudy yellowish brown color with not much of a head at all> Aroma was really sour and funky and citrus. Flet a little flat in the mouth. It seems a little flat but still pretty tastey.

2000 bottle shared by sliffy.  Hazy yellow in color.  The aroma was sour with some hay or grass scents.  The palate was medium.  Nice lemon zest flavor up front wich is lightly sour.  Hints of pepper and grasses throughout.  Very enjoyable.

Weekend of Spontaneous Fermentation 07.  Richer copper body.  Nose is honey & whiskey, light strawberry.  Flavor is bitter up front but plenty of woody vanillan sweetness hiding.  Bittersweet vanilla lemon finish.

2000 Bottle via an in person swap the mysterious Lars: Cloudy golden pour with no head. Aroma, a funky barnyard type aroma, bretty, with an acidic sour note as well. Flavor, light sourness, very funky, and featuring the debut of "horse blanket" in my notes, no carbonation, some lemon and spicy notes as well. This stuff was pretty damn good.
(Bottle 37,5 cl) Pours a hazy, golden with a white head. Distinct, sour Brett and vinegar in the nose. Light and watery body with a very flat feel. Dry, sour vinegar notes. Astringent finish. 100507

UPDATED: SEP 1, 2007 Have had this bottle sitting around for a while and its been well worth the wait. I tried a glass at WSF and, as expected, its much better from the bottle. Pours golden with a thin, fluffy white head. Sour vinegar, grapefruit and cider apple nose. A little hay, barn and yeast in there also. Taste is much the same. Slightly salty with a nice sparkling edge,  the element missing from cask. A tad acidic but quite well balanced overall. As usual, the last pour introduces some sediment which I have actually come to enjoy. Great stuff, De Cam has quickly become a firm favorite, I could easily drink this everyday...*Homer-esque retirement dream bubble of laying on the sofa in front of the tv while sipping this ensues, Mmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmm, Lambiky*

Amber colour, no head. Aroma is earthy, sour druits and some slight wooden bittery notes. Flavour is fruits, wood and big sourness. Very woody aftertaste.

Draught at weekend of spontanious fermentation.
Cloudy orange coloured with no head.
Light acidic aroma of wood and sherry.
Acidic flavour of wood and fruits.
Tart finish.
Bottle. (THX to Papsoe)  Golden / orange colour with a white head. Aroma is sour, fruit, yeast, apple, orange. Flavour is sour, fruit, yeast, apple, orange. Nice beer.

UPDATED: FEB 5, 2012 Draught @ 16th Weekend of Spontaneous Fermentation 2007, Optal.Hazy amber / orange color with virtually none head. Aroma is acidic, fruity, grape, lemon. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and moderate acidic with a average duration. Body is light to medium, texture is watery, carbonation is flat.  8-3-9-3-14 
Bottle 750ml. [ Vintage 2000 ]. Clear medium orange colour with virtually no head. Aroma is moderate horse blanket, barnyard, leather, cow dung, light wood, light black pepper. Flavour is moderate sweet and light light acidic with a average duration, dry, wood, peppery notes. Body is medium, texture is oily to watery, carbonation is flat. [20120127]  8-2-8-4-16

UPDATED: APR 9, 2008 Aroma is smelly, quite barnyard, taste is similar sweaty and sour refreshing a little tart another excellent gueuze. RERATE: Same score, this time far flatter, but same shear drinkability and softness yet amazingly complex.

Bottle, 375ml corked. (thx to papsoe) It pours an unclear, orange, with some white bubbles on top. Barnyard aromas blend with citric and sour scents and is quite pleasant. Citric and acidic flavor with barnyard as well. Astringent, medium mouthfeel. It is a nice lambic, but a bit anonymous. (070510)
UPDATED: APR 25, 2008 Wow. Nice beer very complex taste. Tasted it on draft at the Buggenhout festifal 2007
Bottle at Plan B. Unclear amber - no head - small white edges. Wood (beech - bøg), grape, barnyard, orange, juicy, dirt - dry - bitter. The rule still applies: lick your lips....taste it again.
bottle. murky light orange color. no head. aroma of acid and lemon. bit yeasty and a bit fruity. dry on pallete.
Bottled. Hazy orange golden coloured with almost no head. Very refreshing and well balanced. Notes of lemon and grapefruit. Hints of fruit, wood, barnyard and also kinda earthy. Nice tartness.

A Mes rate: 
37.5cl bottle from Smellerium in that sprouty place. Wow, this is excellent. A lovely aged lambic. 12 years old by the time I got my grubby little mits on it and the bottle conditioning has done its thing superbly. Beautifully delicate carbonation and some of the best looking head and lace I have seen from a straight lambic. Settles in a truely superb manner. Love the copper orange colour too. Citric and acidic in the nose with faint hints of fresh hops. More hops for the finish too. So much sandalwood character in there.  Tart and sour with some lovely butter texture to it also. Ooh there is some rock salt too. Bitter and glorious. Had the complexity of a decent gooz let alone a straight lambic. Glorious stuff.

Bottled Februart 2001. Had a struggle to remove the cork. Cloudy golden-orange. Sharp sweet and spicy fruit aroma with yeast. Taste of grapefruit and tea, sour and bitter. Just the right levels of astringency and acid.

Small white head. Orange colour.
Mushrooms, peanuts and chocolate in the nose. Some maltsweetness.
Acidic flavour with notes of lemon and malt. A bit sweet. Dry finish.
[bottle from Delirium Cafe, Gothenburg] Barnyard aroma, citric, apple, acidic. smooth, drinkable and damned sour. Two thumbs up!

Bottled 2000, so 6 year old. Aroma is still sweetish - amazing - with barnyard and leather. Light hazy, dark yellow color, small off-white head, no lace. What a 3-dimensional flavors! Unbelievable! Sour on the outside and sweet in the inside with a long lasting salty finish. Barnyard, hints of citrus, light bitterness and in the very very end some extra bitterness. Very smooth. Not the complexity of a Girardin Black Label but still wonderful. And I think very accessable, even to people not familiar with beers like this.
A real nice lambiek. Barnyard, acidic, lemon and musty in the nose. Tastes also like balsamico vinegar and a bit cheesy, some wood, lemon and green apples. Complex and refreshing beer.

(Draught at Akkurat, Stockholm 29 April)  Unclear dark golden, big bubbled white head; medium sized nose, quite deep, could be a little more complex: overripe apple, overripe pear but also a little wood and some fresh green apples; the body is very soft (a little to soft), a little watery, very little bitterness; the finish is medium long, it is a bit more sour and tart, then the body: some green apples as well but more sour grapefruit. A very plesant surprise.

(Cask at Akkurat, Stockholm 29 Apr) Colour is dark brown with orange notes, hazy, almost no head. Nose is acidic and musty with hints of stable, leather, horse and some nutty almond notes. Some sulphur in the beginning, but it disappears after a while. Taste is musty, surprisingly fruity, acidic and harsh, initially some sweetness and some bitterness in the finish. Very complex and nice.

Bottle - corked and caged. Februari 2001 vintage. Apple juice in color with almost no head. Nose is VERY sour. Tart fruits, lemon juice, wet dog, damp moldy basement, and the deep forest after rainfall. Taste is slightly less tart than the aroma would let on. Wet wood, sour fruits, light vinegar notes, lemon juice, barnyard and light cat urine. Body is dry, tart and very acidic. Finishes with lots of wet woodiness, lemon juice, damp basement and barnyard notes. Very nice!
Bottledate March 2000. Hazy orange colour with almost no head at all. Barnyard aroma. Very smooth flavor and sour. Some lemon too. Hints of wood too. Long sour aftertaste.

Bottledate February 2001 and brewed 5 years before, so about 10 years old lambiek. Surprised to find that there was still some gas left in the bottle.
Hazy orange with a fine small head. Lemony aroma is very present, oakiness is just in the background. Complex flavours of lemons and wood, the finish even has some nuttiness. Very dry. Soft texture. Definitely a special occasions beer.
Hazy dark gold with a beige head. Baryard funky cheese aroma. Flavour is balanced fruits. Completely dry yet not overtly sour. Nice and very funky.

(RBESG05, bottle) Hazy amber body with minimal off-white head.  Aroma is medium sweet, cheese, horseblanket, yeasty.  Taste is mild sweet, cheese, some lemon, horseblanket.  Soft light body with some acidity.

Bottle at Plan B during RBESG 05 pub crawl. Proper Lambic funk aroma. Good stuff. Sour, super smooth. Milky body, tangy all the way. Slips down lovely. Nice stuff feels genuine, and I enjoyed it more than their Gueuze. (Glad I hassled Dr Beer for some of this!)
Pours misty golden. Almost no head. Sourish, yeasty nose. Flavour from pear and apples. Lots of yeast in finish.

Hazy golden, gentle white ring. Deep slightly citrusy nose, lactic and well ponctuated with yeasty horseblanket. Good lemon juice acidity, all in all well blended and smooth, fairly light. truly appealing and diplomatic, close to a 9 for the nose. It doesnt quite hold up in flavor where it is juicy, horsey and astringent. There is this herbal bite that feels almost like a tame jalapeno, which would be paired with a straight hay juice shot. Flavors finish very quick and are far more chaotic than in the nose. Correct mouthfeel on the other hand, a bit light, but fully carbonated if the bubbles dont last very long.

Sampled from bottle at RBSG 2005 post-Cider Tour Sunday Imperial Stouts are tiggmtls Favorite Syle No Lie tasting.  Dark dirty/oily gold with visible head and light carbonation...sourdough yeast, sharp lemons and huge brett in the nose, massive and overpowering...body soft, sour, quite dry, musty and a bit thin, with a rather watery finish...feels a bit old though its only a 2001 bottled in 2003.  Still very glad to be able to try it, thanks so much cquiroga!

2001 Bottle sampled @ RBSG 05 (Montréal) Post-Cidery Impromptu Hotel Room TastingLight hazy blonde, nice head, light lacing. Nose of bright tart barnyard, swimming with tartness fruit and some cherry. If I was Augustus Gloop and it was a river of tart cherries, Id be knowing his fate. The flavor is not as intense, dry and musky like a damp cellar. Finishes fizzy and light.

Pears and lemons wrapped in leather on the barnyard floor.  Hazy orange-gold with low white head that diminishes to ring and swirling cover.  Short pear flavour is strongly acidic, tart and fairly bitter but offers little in the way of body.  Low carbonation leaves this one feeling sadly lifeless.  Bottle (2001 marked 2001) sampled at the post RBSG05 hotel tasting.  Many thanks to cquiroga for sharing!

07.10.05  Bottle, RBSG.  Brewed Feb 01, Bottled 2003.  Soft, sour, much hay, wet morning farm.  Fantastic balance on nose, but flavor in not keeping up.  Palate is flat, astringent feel across teeth.  Not as old or sour as expected, but very nice.  Color is pretty, light straw, melted honey.

(bottle from Belgian Belly, Manchester).  Apparently this is Lindemans lambic matured in the wooden casks from Prazdroj in Plzen.  Fairly flat beer with a nice prickle.  Lots of lemons and citrus aromas and taste with some mandarin oranges too.  Full bodied malty and grainy flavour, lots of sourness and bitterness with noticeable hops in the horseblankety sour and citrus finish.  A lovely drink.
Hazy golden with no head. Soft dilicate taste some sour acidic aftertaste. Aroma is nice and bit acidic.
Handpumped @ Akkurat, Stockholm. 10 May 2005Labeled 5.5%. Creamy head. Soft and nice velvet palate with some (virginia) tobacco quite appearent.
Yellow/golden, white head. Sourish citrus aroma with hops and grapefruit. Sourish in flavor as well, vinous and with some bitterness.

2000 bottle, Waterhuis, Ghent, Nov 04.

Head is initially small, fizzy, white, mostly diminishing.
Body is hazy dark yellow, bottle conditioned.

Aroma is moderately yeasty (horseblanket, barnyard), with notes of wood, lemon, and grape.

Flavor is moderately sweet, heavily acidic.
Finish is lightly sweet, moderately acidic, lightly bitter.

Medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation, moderately astringent.

Delicious, wonderfully balanced, and aromatic, a real treat.

Bottled march 00. The lambic is five years old before bottled, according to the label. Light orange color. The aroma has lemon, mandarin, even hints of raspberry and butter. Almost no carbon. Dusty flavor with a moderate sourness. Oak, mandarin, lemon and pineapple. It is a lambic that is both complex, traditional and easy to drink. Just below the absolute top. Wish I had bought more.

(Bottled 03/2000, 0.375l) Hazy, golden-orange color with almost no head. Very sour, slightly fruity aroma. Sour, semi-dry flavor with a quick, sour finish. Moderately carbonated, quite smooth, medium-bodied, dryish palate. A surprisingly enjoyable, not overly sour, but definitely not sweet lambic. Quite plain, still.
Copenhagen beer marathon 2004, Hazy golden color, heavy farm sour aroma, sour taste, medium body, dry finish.

Aroma of citrus fruits, oak, some pepper. Hazy, orange coloured with not much head. Taste is sweet, tart, fruity (citrus), oak, some pepper and lactic/cheezy notes. Aftertaste is not very tart, quite sweet and smooth/soft. Dry. Lacking some complexness and balance.
Sour aroma, not overwhelming but pleasant. Hazy orange body, small airy bubbles. Barnyard flavor, good amount of sourness, dry.

Bottled - St Albans Beer Festival.  Joe got in early to grab some of this before it sold so Im glad he liked it so much.  A cloudy orange coloured lambic (almost blood orange colour) with a sour apple fusty farmyard and blue cheese aroma (in other words loads going on).  The taste starts off challengingly sour but then the juicy fruit kicks in.  its good but not perfect.

My 700th rating. 375ml Bottle conditioned @ the Saturday session, St Albans Beer Festival 2004. 2000 bottling.. Beer of the festival. Low carbonation. A fine lambic, softer than you would expect a Gueuze to be but perhaps sharper/dryer than Girardin draught lambic, for instance. The beer is sour and fairly dry, with lots of lemon/citrus.

Apples and a litle citrus in the nose along with other funky, pungent aromas. Dark hazy amber with no head. Apply malt taste turning quickly sour. Very astringent and it dries the teeth after the swallow. Great balance and an excellent lambic. One of the better lambics.

Bottled 03.2000.  Clear amber body with no head.  Virtually still.  Aroma of light fruit and funky yeast.  Apple skins, lemon, leather, barnyard brett, hay, a little cheese, a bit of iron, musty wood, and white grape.  The body is average.  The flavors are good, starting slightly sweet and moving to a significant tartness that leaves the tongue yearning for more.  Tasty, but I think I prefer my lambic blended for Geuze.

Aroma features mold, green cheese and hay - overall  fresh though.
Cloudy apricot, low head.
Extremely dry, barn and leather plus the atromanotes.
Excellent!
Belgianbeerweekend, Brussels 2004: What a nice treat: Light cherry nose, orange color. Taste is cobbwebs, chalk, woody, earthy with pine forest touches. Astringent dry.

Draught at Akkurat, Stockholm, if my memory serves me right. 
Very pale golden. Nose is plain with only a discrete sourness. Flavour is sour with notes of overripe apples. Mouthfeel is clean and a bit watery.
Cloudy dull tan.  Rich lambic aroma - smelly shoes, farms, washed-rind cheeses, cork and other fun things.  Mostly flat, finishing slightly sweet (for the style), but its good lambic.

(bottle, sampled at Akkurat, Stockhol, Sweden) Clear golden with a small bybbly head. Woody and cheesy aroma. Woody flavour with a flat carbonation. Semi-dry. Small notes of grapefruit, wood and cheese in finish. Soft mouthfeel.

Bottle- once again props to chris_o for sharing this beer, last beer of the night, and its a good thing we stopped because i think we were pushing it at this stage. Completely still on the pur, acidic, lemony and dry, but not as assertive or complex as i would have liked. Was a little dissapointed (even though it was still very tasty), because i am a huge fan of the Oude Gueuze.

1995 lambic bottled in 2000 and drank in 2004. Poured a pale hazy yellow beer with almost no carbonation, which was to be expected. Nose of citrus and a bit of acidity. Taste is quite dry and sour with a surprising but welcome subtle sweet ending. Again notes of citrus (lemon/lime) are present.  Im not expert on what should unblended bottle lambic should taste like but I can say that this was a real good experience. Too bad I probably wont be able to get my hand on some of this again.

35th, and final, beer with Duff (and, earlier, SilkTork and Spiesy) at Catford Beer Festival. this was my very first straight lambic and I had enjoyed the Oude Gueuze from the same producer very much when I sampled it a couple of days earlier. I guess the circumstances were not exactly ideal for my first experience of this style, but although this was still tart, lemony and woody, it was far softer than the Gueuze, which, overall, I preferred. Stiil pretty good stuff. Time for bed.

(Bottled old lambic) Pale, hazy chromate yellow; slim white rim. Citric, horse blanket, saddlesoap, wood and sulphur - all the ingredients for a classic lambic nose. Dry, citric, slightly lactic and fruity taste (not tasting very much as old lambic). Not much of a palate. Very dry. Aftertaste is again very sour, both lactic, grapefruit, citric. Very good lambid, but not very distinctive lambic. Its still searching its real potential. (More than) good points for the try, anyway.
Bottled. Hazy pale orange. Hay and cobweb aroma. Barnyardy with medium acidity, fairly hard, dense mouthfeel. Strikingly hoppy for a lambic. Bitter finish with a touch of iron.
Cloudy orange color, very short white head. Aroma is quite typical gueuze, some wood, hint of hop. Taste is quite sharp and flat. I prefer the oude gueuze from De Cam, which is more balanced.

UPDATED: MAY 9, 2004 Bottled februari 2001, sampled may 2004. Cloudy orange coloured, little head. Fantastic tart gueuze aroma, wood and some fruit. Smooth flavour, obviously sour and tart with some wood. Initially watery finish, which later on gets more complex. Very good lambic, too bad its not that easily available.

UPDATED: NOV 12, 2013 2013-07-24, corked 37cl bottle from Erzbierschof, Bernbottled Jan 2009, 4+ years old, 8-4-7-4-15=38Uncorked without pop, it pours a just hazy golden color, with few big bubbles and small sparse head. The aroma is pungent, with cellar smell, cat pee, some lemon. Dry mouthfeel, with acceptable carbonation; pleasant sourness, with a sharp lemony character; but at first it also has a very pleasant impression of fox grapes, and later of cedar; dry and astringent in the final.Very enjoyable in this hot summer afternoon.2004-04-23, 8-3-6-3-12=32Cloudy blond color. Nice sour, lemony aroma. Uncommon taste, some residual sweetness; lemon juice and lemon peel, astringent, quite sour. Pleasant, for the thirst, not exceptional.

Pours a hazy golden body with almost no head (of course!). Aroma is sour from the wild fermentation with wood and grapefruit notes. Nice and well-balanced. Flavor is very tart woody and grapefruity with a dry finish. Bites my tongue! A really nice and complex lambic. 


Thanks to Jens (Ungstrup) for sharing!

Bottled 2002: Yellow/orange coloured. White head. Earthy with an intense sourness. Fresh acidic flavour. The sourness is perfectly balanced by a slightly sweetness. This is good stuff. Is fresh and dry in the aftertaste with some fruity sourness. Thanks Jens for sharing.

[Vintage 1995, bottled 2000, sampled 2004] The color is a hazy dark yellow and it has a small lasting white head. The aroma is very nice sharp and sour - just like a lambic should be. The flavor is a sharp fresh lambic flavor with notes of lemon. The end is very dry and lemony. It is somewhat flat from low carbonation, but it is very fresh for a beer bottle 4 years ago and brewed 9 years ago. A great lambic.
